nit: as template mentions, we should probably put a discord nickname or at least an email here I think, so that people can reach out for help / clarification
This section needs some prose as part of it, what exists today, what is the status quo for this kind of thing, how have other systems used this.
Got it. I will enrich this section.
nit: Using amarkdown reader to view this, it seems this \ shows up

Could you elaborate more for why do I need to remove this?
From the design template it says
```
Background and References
(1-2 paragraphs) What background context is necessary? You should mention related work inside and outside of OpenBMC. What other Open Source projects are trying to solve similar problems? Try to use links or references to external sources (other docs or Wikipedia), rather than writing your own explanations. Please include document titles so they can be found when links go bad. Include a glossary if necessary. Note: this is background; do not write about your design, specific requirements details, or ideas to solve problems here.
```
I think put some background context and example should be okay.

It's a little confusing but I think Willy pointed out to remove the trailing `\`

From the email that's easier to read:

```
Patch Set #2, Line 24: \

rm
```

Which, I also pointed out and you fixed - so I'll mark this resolved.

oh got it.
Sorry the whole section has been highlighted so I thought you mean to delete the whole section.

I think these kind of lists work better in markdown if you list them as bullets from the start:

* 5 boot up...
    * one of its usages
* google misc. ,,,
I still don't like this terminology. Can't it just be Powercycle and Host/Mobo Reboot?
I THINK this is an industry-wide term, but someone else can confirm

I had discussed these 2 terms with many people including bios and hardware before finalize.
I am okay with changing these terms, but I think it would be better to have more discussion before we decide.

From the discussion with Ed in the comment, I changed the terms
AC power cycle -> S0_G3_S0
DC power cycle -> S0_S5_S0

It will meet the definition here: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Control/Power/ACPIPowerState.interface.yaml#L15-L62
nit: using a markdown viewer, this table is ill-formed, could you please check again?

That's one of the issue. All those tables show correctly on my vscode md preview.

I used our internal md formatter, it should be okay now.
No problem, it looks correct now!
such as the type of the power cycle (AC or DC)

No.. sorry this is my first time writing doc with markdown.
I am still getting used to it.
nit: continue from the previous sentence: ... is changing, but these host efforts won't be in scope of this doc.
might want to wrap the T_* in backticks (` `) so that they look more like variables

Need to mention what's different if the BMC also go down. What data will be lost and how that will affect the duration.

As noted internally, the BMC time get synced to the host once that booted up. How do we make sure that the time doesn't get synced in between calculating the duration. Or should that be a requirement that it doesn't sync (not practical).

Or maybe it should only be synced after all the calculations are completed.

> Need to mention what's different if the BMC also go down. What data will be lost and how that will affect the duration.
I will add a section for ungraceful/abnormal power cycles.

> As noted internally, the BMC time get synced to the host once that booted up. How do we make sure that the time doesn't get synced in between calculating the duration. Or should that be a requirement that it doesn't sync (not practical).
> Or maybe it should only be synced after all the calculations are completed.
In this design BMC doesn’t need to sync the time with the host. And it won’t affect anything even BMC does.
BMC uses an internal monotonic timer as the timestamp (not wall clock time). When host notify BMC, BMC will read the monotonic timer and record it.
I think you mean something liek "Can this be done with host notification only?"
make this one sentence (similar to a suggestion above)
nit: just continue the sentence instead of .

Thanks for reviewing in detail.
I ran the internal md formatter on this file.
Hope the format issues can be fixed.
nit: this is basically the subject. Should we just remove it from the body
This is probably good to be reviewed by the maintainers of openbmc/docs now

How about this? I try to describe the problems instead of the implementations.

During a server reboot/power cycle process, measuring the duration spent on each [stage](#definition-of-each-stage) is the key to profiling and monitoring the software quality. However, some parts of the flow are not easy to be measured and exposed to host user space applications. For example, it's impossiblt to measure the time spent on Linux kernel shutting down because the file system might be unavailable at the end of kernel reboot process.
Thanks! I think it's more clear.
Can you add a section for BMC and host shutting down together? I think BMC will be faster than host in this scenario. (AC cycle)

Sorry I don't get your point.
What will be the content inside this section?
I believed the AC power cycle flow is included already.
I meant the power cycle reboot method seems to terminate BMC and host at the same time. It's normal process. So readers won't expect to find information in that abnormal reboot event section.

I don't have `abnormal reboot` section in this doc. While I have a similiar section called `unexpected power cycle`. In that section the AC power cycle case is included since this kind of AC power cycle is unexpected from the host aspect (for bmc it's expected, while bmc doesn't inform host so it's unexpected for host).

I'm thinking from the reader's perspective. The reboot flow, defined in the beautiful ASCII diagram, explicitly put the BMC shutdown after host completing shutdown. However, in some cases, tray power cycle reboot flow actually shut BMC and host down at the same time. This is may be by design. It would be nice to have a short subsection that mentioned this case explicitly. However, like you mentioned, actually this is defined in `unexpected power cycle`. It's just a bit unclear to the reader that the expected shutdown flow is explained in `unexpected power cycle`.

As we discussed offline.
I changed `BMC shutdown` to `Post Shutdown`.
Also added a section `Where is BMC shutdown?` to describe it.
since the main focus is to monitor boot time/power satus, it  can be also named as btmonitor ?
Might be good to add the actual Maintainers to take a look at this point

Oh.. I thought Ed is one of the maintainer.
Just added maintainers as reviewer.
I'm a core maintainer, I'm not a docs maintainer, although I do review here quite a bit.
This seems kind of odd, and it's not "impossible", as there have been other systems that rely on serial consoles to measure it.

Yes, we can have another consumer to capture and analyze the host serial console log to measure the duration.
However this consumer can't be an userspace application running on host. It can be run on BMC or any other component that is capable to access host serial console.

So what I'm trying to explain in this section is that we can't rely on host to measure the host bootup/shutdown durations by its own.
Can we make sure these terms are the same as the terms already used on the dbus power interfaces?  I think they're a little different.

I think you are talking about this: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Control/Power/ACPIPowerState.interface.yaml#L15-L62

I think I can make the term change as below:
```
AC power cycle -> S0_G3_S0
DC power cycle -> S0_S5_S0
```
For the term `Stage` and `Unmeasured`, I think they are specific to this design, I don't find an appropriate replacement.

Is this change okay for you?

Yep, I was referring to the power state things here:
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/b1de713e0fd8fe307a60ef65f3c353136fa6dc96/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/Chassis.interface.yaml#L68


Sure, stage and unmeasured are fine.

```
AC power cycle -> S0_G3_S0
DC power cycle -> S0_S5_S0
```
Replaced
On naming, can we not abbreviate "boot time".  "bt" could also mean bluetooth, and regardless of that "bt" is not very descriptive.

Okay... So do you prefer not abbreviate at all (BootTimeMonitor)?
I am okay with that althought it's a bit too long to me.
No abbreviation is a big improvement.
Yes, BootTimeMonitor is MUCH more descriptive.  Our goal is to be descriptive in naming, not attempt to have short names.
Reopening, commit message still says "btmonitor" as does the filename.  Did you mean to upload a new patch?

In your background section, can you please talk about the existing https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/BMC.interface.yaml

And why it can't be extended to add your use cases?

I will add a section discussing this.

Short answer:

This design doc is focusing on the host reboot process (BMC reboot is also included but not the main purpose) .
While `State/BMC.interface` focus on the BMC states, which doesn't meet our needs.

Answer in the background section of your next patch please.

> BMC reboot is also included but not the main purpose

This is kind of what I'm pointing out, does the BMC monitoring need to stay in the existing bmc monitoring daemons, and the host monitoring things go into this new daemon?

> While `State/BMC.interface` focus on the BMC states, which doesn't meet our needs.

Looking forward to the details of that getting answered in your next patch.

> This is kind of what I'm pointing out, does the BMC monitoring need to stay in the existing bmc monitoring daemons, and the host monitoring things go into this new daemon?

Yes, but it requires the existing bmc monitoring daemons to record some data that BootTimeMonitor needs.
For example: BootTimeMonitor needs the timestamp right before power-off (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/google-misc/+/54422/9/subprojects/btmanager/service_files/record-down-end.service.in). This will be one of the things needs to be export by the existing bmc monitoring daemons.

> Looking forward to the details of that getting answered in your next patch.

I will update the content asap.

Rephrase the section `## Background and References`.
I explain which dbus interface we can use and which we can't in that section.
`State/BMC.interface` also included.
Please add more detail.  "export" isn't a great term.  Does this mean Redfish?  IPMI?  BOth?

Both. I added more details in it.
```
-   Capability to export any additional duration that the user required to DBus.
    These additional durations can be consumed by Redfish or IPMI blob, depends
    on the needs.
```

Can you add an explanation of *why* exposing a DBus interface is a requirement? What other component is consuming this information? For instance, why can't this instead be recovered from structured logging to the journal?

> What other component is consuming this information?

In my plan the consumer will be Redfish and IPMI blob.

> Can you add an explanation of *why* exposing a DBus interface is a requirement?

In my plan all the information will be consumed by Redfish and IPMI blob. And the DBus is the main interprocess communication system in BMC. So I think the DBus interface is a requirement.

Just so we're clear, I'd like that response in the wording of the requirement.

Also, can you add a pointer to the redfish schema that would expose this data? Some discussion of the IPMI blob structure would be good too.

This is the reboot cause of the BMC. I am looking for the power cycle type of host.

Here is the host state https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/Host.interface.yaml#L87.
I might be able to leverage that. 
However I am not sure if we can map each `RestartCause` to `AC/DC`.
For example, if the `RestartCause` is `Unknown` or `RemoteCommand`, then we might not able to distinguish it's AC or DC.
So maybe add an "Unknown" reboot state to the list of enums for when we can't distinguish?  We might want to look at what x86-power-control does here.
Done, I also elaborated more in the `Power cycle type` section.
I would've expected some answer to "Why aren't we using the existing interfaces for this?"

Ah I see.
In fact I don't have a strong reason for not using existing interfaces.
I rephrase the `Power cycle type` section to indicate that we will directly use `RestartCause`.
Also updated the `Requirements` section
"Receive required commands" needs more details.  All dbus deamons receive commands.
Aren't IPMI blobs already supported, of which this would just be a new type?

We need a new OEM subcommand to support
1. receiving the notification
2. adding additional
Code like this: https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/google-ipmi-sys/+/49367/24/commands.hpp
More details in that area (which commands) would be good.

I added a section for describing the new OEM command format.
`### What do the OEM commands look like?`

Hope this can answer your question.
Just something to be aware of, considering that we have multi-host systems in the queue, this needs to account for that.

I didn't consider that scenario.
Can this doc focus on single host scenario first?
Then supporting multi-host afterwards.

No, I think we need to give some thought to multi-host and its impact on any interfaces required now. I don't want to require breaking changes across the tree to cope with a future requirement that we're aware of now.

That's a good point to think of. From our view, we assume that there is one main host that can represent the up/down status of a machine. This means:
1. as long as the main host is booted, the whole machine is considered as booted/up.
2. the rest of the hosts can be booted in parallel of the main host or after the main host is up. If the main host needs to wait for the other hosts before it's considered as up, the time will be counted in the userspace stage.
3. the breakdown durations of other hosts are stored in durations, which is very flexible to store any data.
4. the stage time covers only the contributors to wall clock time in a boot flow. In other words, we treat the boot flow as a linear flow of stages in order to have a meaningful breakdown of total boot time.

For scenarios of two or more main hosts, there are two possible solutions.
1. only treat one of them as the main host, only the main management host is the main host. (this will be what I explained above)
2. store and repot the data of all the hosts separately. (this needs a few implementation change to identify the host but the doc design should be very similar)

Feel free to comments on the ideas. Multi-host is quite a new concept.

> Can this doc focus on single host scenario first?

Considering that multi-host systems were proposed first, I don't think we can do it that way.  In terms of _implementation_ you can certainly start with the single-host case first, but in terms of design, we need to think about it here so we don't box ourselves into a corner.  Considering we're adding handlers to Redfish and IPMI, it behooves us to think about this now.

>  as long as the main host is booted, the whole machine is considered as booted/up.

In something like a yosemite, which node is the "Main host"?  They're all pretty equal, no?

Agreed. Let's focus on single machine for now but keep the design doc flexible. So, basically, variables/data should be wrapped in a list of struct, storing data from different hosts. As for identifying the host ID, we should have a common infrastructure to enumerate/label the hosts. It's important to keep the host mapping consistent across all SW. I would expect something from the IPMI command telling me where the command source is. Also, somewhere in the BMC, we can query the host ID mapping or similar things. So, we don't need to change our IPMI command design to support sending host ID from the host side. WDYT? What's the current plan for identifying/mapping data from different hosts for other components?

I was talking about some hypothetical situation. Although there are multiple hosts, but the whole machine is serving for one purpose, like a replica or a big storage tray. Thus, there will be synchronization event somewhere in user service or other places. There will be a main node that is responsible to respond to connections and distribute the tasks to other hosts. Once a connection is ready, the client can transfer data to sub-hosts directly.

It's not a common model for most multi-hosts machines. It's a more specialized design. This kind of single machine model can also be a transition stage between single-host to multi-host in a datacenter.

> Agreed. Let's focus on single machine for now but keep the design doc flexible. So, basically, variables/data should be wrapped in a list of struct, storing data from different hosts.

You say "focus on the design" but then you jump immediately into the implementation (by talking about structs and data storage).

> As for identifying the host ID, we should have a common infrastructure to enumerate/label the hosts.

This already exists in the dbus interfaces.

> It's important to keep the host mapping consistent across all SW. I would expect something from the IPMI command telling me where the command source is.

Yep, and because this would be a breaking change to the IPMI command, this is why we call it out now in the design phase.

> Also, somewhere in the BMC, we can query the host ID mapping or similar things. So, we don't need to change our IPMI command design to support sending host ID from the host side. WDYT?

?  I don't understand this statement.  Any IPMI command we add would need to be aware of what host you're asking for the data from.

> What's the current plan for identifying/mapping data from different hosts for other components?

There are already components that do this today using dbus, and patches in review for others.

> 
> I was talking about some hypothetical situation. Although there are multiple hosts, but the whole machine is serving for one purpose, like a replica or a big storage tray. Thus, there will be synchronization event somewhere in user service or other places. There will be a main node that is responsible to respond to connections and distribute the tasks to other hosts. Once a connection is ready, the client can transfer data to sub-hosts directly.

At a manageability level, this doesn't really affect the BMC if there are software orchestration layers for the hosts.  We just see them as hosts, each with an independent state.

> 
> It's not a common model for most multi-hosts machines. It's a more specialized design. This kind of single machine model can also be a transition stage between single-host to multi-host in a datacenter.

We're literally going through that transition now, which is why it's mentioned in your design doc.

Extending this design to support multi-host needs a few prerequisites.

1. BMC needs to be able to differentiate where the IPMI command comes from (which host is sending the IPMI command).
2. `xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host` provider needs to support multi-host.

If these 2 are fulfilled, then BootTtimeMonitor can easily save the boot time info for each host separately.
From the discussion above, it seems like 1) is still ongoing. Not sure if 2) is supported or not.

Will update the multi-host scenario into doc.

--------------------------------------------

Quick explanation for the `main host` that Medicine mentioned above.
We are considering 2 scenarios:

1. All the hosts are equal and power on simultaneously. In this case all the hosts will be treated the same (This should be what you expected).
2. `main`/`sub` hosts. For example:
If the server uses a smartNIC which has a linux kernel in it. Then this smartNIC can be treated as a host. However this `smartNIC host` has to be fully power-on within the `loader` stage in `main host`. In this case either treating the `smartNIC host` as a host or not is fine. Since the time elapsed in `smartNIC host` already been accumulated into `loader` stage.

I added multi-host support in the requirement.
I didn't write too much becuase it's not hard as long as we can differentiate the IPMI command is sending from which host.

Hi Ed, thanks for replying.
I need to discuss with Medicine about some details of your questions.
Will update within 1~2 days.
nit, this isn't a requirement, that's an implementation detail.  It is likely the right solution, but DBus itself is not a requirement, given that dbus isn't user facing.

Take out from the requirements.
New version only says `Allow users to save extra (arbitrary) durations.`
Then put details in `Proposed design`
This needs some details.  What Redfish properties are required?
Remove the redfish part from this design. `BMCWeb` might be one of the consumer of this service. But it is not part of the the design.
This seems to be repeated, and from the requirements, it's not clear what these other services would be inside the bmc that need the information.  Please clarify.

Take out from the requirements.

> it's not clear what these other services would be inside the bmc that need the information.  Please clarify.

I think machine-health related daemon will be interested in this information since boot time is one of the factor of performance.
Given that this interface already exists, why would a client use the bt managers version of the interface instead?

Because `Host.RestartCause` is aiming for `why` this reboot is been performed. While we plan to export `what` kind of reboot.
If we can clearly map every `Host.RestartCause` to a certain reboot type (halt/reboot) then we can still use that.
This is the first mention of measuring "retry"  can you give some definition to that?
Third mention of a dbus interface, which is not external facing.  Dbus is an implementation detail, not a requirement.
Take it out from the requirement and put in the implementation.
This is good!  Please add some more details about what data will be in this blob.
Done. Put more details in the `IPMI blob` section.
Why are both blobs and new oem commands required?

From my understanding a lightweight communication shouldn't use blob.
So I choose IPMI OEM command to send the notification/duration since the command is trivial and use blob to received the boot flow and durations.

If using OEM+blob is not recommanded. We can only use one of them.
this will be hosted in OpenBMC OEM, right?

You go into lots of detail above, which is great, but I don't see any mention of the most important things:
1. What does the user-facing API look like?
2. What is the connection between the various daemons?
3. Which daemons are fundamentally in charge of what pieces?

You have a mention about multi-host, but I see no mention of it in the above design, where the multiple hosts will be aggregated.

> 1. What does the user-facing API look like?
`Interfaces` section describe this part.

> 2. What is the connection between the various daemons?
DBus

> 3. Which daemons are fundamentally in charge of what pieces?
There will be 1~3 daemons in this design.

1. One for handling IPMI OEM command. (Can be merged to existing proper daemon. In Google we have https://github.com/openbmc/google-ipmi-sys)
2. One for handling IPMI blob transfer. (Can be merged to existing proper daemon. https://github.com/openbmc/google-misc/tree/master/subprojects/metrics-ipmi-blobs)
3. One for handling all other functionalities.

Only the third one is required. The first 2 can be merged into proprt exsiting daemon.

I'm not sure I agree with that.  phosphor-watchdog is intended to monitor the host state, and already has a number of these interfaces already.  Can you talk through the technical details of why this is required.

> phosphor-watchdog is intended to monitor the host state,
From my understanding `phosphor-watchdog` is mainly for checking whether host is alive or not.
Got pet = alive
No pet = dead

In that case watchdog doesn't know why the host is petting/not petting. Nor what state is host at.
So put the reboot process profiling in this repo doesn't look right to me.

These sections are important, and the lack of detail here kind of brings attention to what I commented earlier about the lack of system-level design in this doc.  Which new applications will be needed and who will maintain them is an important thing in this document.

Updated.
In the latest version I mentioned that we can put this design as part of `phosphor-state-manager`
But I am okay to have an individual repo as well.
Surely some level of robot tests and unit tests are required?

Yes, unit test will cover most of the case of this design.
The most important test is to ensure that all the state-transition has been cover so there is no surprise for the state machine.

```
-   Unittest for each individual functions
-   Mock the state change of `CurrentHostState` to ensure an unexpected reboot
    can be handled correctly.
-   Mock the receiving IPMI command to ensure the state-transition is expected.
```
Which machine types will support this feature?

Testing plan is updated.
We can pretend we receive IPMI OEM command from host by mocking it.
Added Andrew Geissler as reviewer since he is the maintainer of `phosphor-state-manager`
nit: these "\" are not needed in markdown docs

I was excited at the start of the doc to see reference to using BootProgress as that's a generic d-bus property that anyone can update. For example, on our IBM systems, we utilize PLDM as the communication protocol between the BMC and Host. That path updates the BootProgress property. Is there a way to at least make a generic D-Bus property here that could be updated by IPMI or PLDM so others could utilize this function? Or maybe xyz/openbmc_project/Time/Boot is the generic object that BootProgress OR IPMI OEM could update?

> Or maybe xyz/openbmc_project/Time/Boot is the generic object that BootProgress OR IPMI OEM could update?

That a great idea! I planed to use IPMI only to received notification and durations. But having a generic DBus property is more flexible for other interfaces.
Will update the doc.

I wonder if by default we could just use BootProgress/CurrentHostState (getting more limited information), and if a config flag is passed in, we rely on the IPMI OEM path on those systems to update it instead?

Yes, we could.
In that case we need to utilize the properties inside `BootProgress/CurrentHostState` to classify the boot process and define the state-transition table.

For example (This might be incorrect. Just an example)
C:CurrentHostState B:BootProgress
(C)Running->(C)TransitioningToOff->(C)Off->(B)BusInit->(B)MemoryInit->(B)OSStart->(B)OSRunning

However I don't think it's easy because many states of `CurrentHostState` and `BootProgress` are overlapped. So the state-transition will be very complicated in this case.

ok thanks, maybe something IBM team could work on after you get the base implementation in place. Just having the design generic enough to support non-IPMI mechanisms to use this function will be appreciated. Just having the timing information between the BootProgress steps would be very interesting to us.

The phosphor-state-manager-host package is usually not utilized by systems using x86-power-control so this would have to be a separate package within phosphor-state-manager. Which I think is fine to host the d-bus object and interface (but not any of the IPMI code logic that sets the d-bus object)

> The phosphor-state-manager-host package is usually not utilized by systems using x86-power-control so this would have to be a separate package within phosphor-state-manager.

Yes, that's the plan.
So this feature will be involved in `phosphor-state-manager` while it's a separated package.

> Which I think is fine to host the d-bus object and interface (but not any of the IPMI code logic that sets the d-bus object)

Yes, this is a good idea. I will update the doc to use DBus object and interface to receive the notification and duration.
IPMI code logic will be in another repository.

High level I think this will be a useful feature. Tracking boot progress and timings is something a lot of people are interested in. I didn't review much of the technical details around IPMI or the actual time calculations.
Have you put any thought into how we could retrieve this timing data via Redfish from external clients?

Yes, I was planning to propose new Redfish schema to DMTF because I didn't find proper schema for now.
However it haven't been done so currently there is no good Redfish schema to store timing data.
Thus I removed Redfish part since the implementation won't have anything related to Redfish.

I'm not going to use this IPMI feature on my systems but high level, it seems like you're really intertwining the host and BMC firmware here. Why not keep it generic where host just sends a "I reached this point" like it does with BootProgress and have the time and duration calculations all done on the BMC? i.e. why does the host need to be tracking all this timing info between steps now?

Sorry I didn't elaborate clearly. Current design is the same as you said.

During the host boot up, the only thing that host needs to tell BMC is "I reached this point", "I reached that point". That's the purpose of `Notify` command.

The command `SetDuration` is for additional/extra durations (It's optional)
For example, we may initiate the smart NIC during the `Loader` stage and we want to track how long it takes as well.
In that case the host can utilize `SetDuration` command to tell BMC: "Help me to report this timing info to DBus". So that other BMC Daemons can use it.

For the purpose of last command `SetRebootType` is that BMC can't distinguish the host reboot is `Halt` or `Reboot` by itself. So we need host to told us. (This also optional)
